awd_titl_txt: CAREER: The restricted nonlinear framework: A new paradigm for modeling, analysis and control of wall-bounded turbulent flows
awd_abstract_narration:
A restricted nonlinear framework for modeling, analysis and control of wall-bounded turbulent flows project will develop a suite of models and tools for studying the characteristics of flow over surfaces. These flow properties have important implications in transport applications, where the interaction between the vehicle surface and the air flowing over it leads to increased friction drag and associated reductions in fuel efficiency. Wind farms are another related application, in which the air flowing over the farm interacts with both the ground and the wind turbines leading to flow patterns that directly impact the efficiency of the farm.  The state-of-the-art mathematical models of the flow physics tend to be extremely complex and of high-dimension, which makes them hard to analyze and computationally expensive to simulate. The resulting models will be used to both study the flow phenomena, and to improve the accuracy of certain state-of-the-art computational tools that employ models of certain aspects of the flow to reduce the computational burden of numerical studies. Outreach activities at local Baltimore elementary schools and through a JHU summer program for high school students will therefore emphasize the connections between fundamental fluid mechanics and sustainable energy in order to put the mathematics and science they are learning in the context of pressing societal concerns.   

This project will develop a novel reduced order modeling framework that seeks to help overcome the challenges of characterizing wall-bounded turbulent flows, which is complicated by both the analytical intractability of the governing equations, and the associated large computational costs of fully resolved simulations.  In particular, the proposed research will develop the core theory and simulation tools to extend restricted nonlinear (RNL) modeling principles to wall models for large eddy simulations (LES), high Reynolds number boundary layer flows and wind farm flow fields. The RNL model is a reduced-order model for wall-turbulence that is obtained through a dynamical restriction of the Navier-Stokes (NS) equations that leads to both simplified dynamics and an intrinsic order reduction, resulting in vastly reduced analytical and computational complexity. The expected outcomes of this work include a suite of tools for (i) analyzing and isolating key flow phenomena, (ii) developing mechanistic models of key flow processes, (iii) improving the accuracy of LES (through a RNL wall model), and (iv) designing model-based wind farm control strategies.  The research is tightly coupled with an education and outreach plan that includes training of two graduate students as well as activities for elementary and high school students illustrating the application of mathematics and science to improve the efficiency of wind energy.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project was to develop and use reduced order models to better understand wall-bounded shear flows.  To types of classes of models were employed:  a novel analytical tool for transitional flows and a dynamic model that was extended for use in a wide range of fully developed turbulent regimes. These models were used to isolate and analyze key flow phenomena, investigate control strategies and improve the fidelity of flow simulation tools (though new wall models for large eddy simulations). 

Intellectual Merit: The project developed a novel analytical method to identify and characterize the types of disturbances most likely to induce transition in wall-bounded shear flows. This so-called structured input-output analysis approach builds upon widely used input-output methods by including nonlinear effects through a problem reformulation that enables calculation of these disturbances using tools from robust control theory (mu analysis). The results are demonstrated on a wide range of configurations including plane Couette flow, channel flow and stratified flows. In the stratified setting the approach was employed to understand the changes in the dominant flow structures over the parameters of interest (Reynolds and Prantl numbers), enabling the interpretation of previous findings in the literature. This modeling framework has opened up new avenues for evaluating control design. The original paper won the "Corrsin-Kovasznay Outstanding Paper Award, which recognizes a young JHU scholar who is lead author of a recent paper in fluid mechanics for the work’s excellence, originality and potential impact."

The other focus of the project was extensions to the Restricted Nonlinear (RNL) Modeling framework to higher Reynolds number and nonequilibrium flows (e.g., flow over rough surfaces).  Extensions to higher Reynolds number included both the development and validation of a restricted nonlinear large eddy simulation (RNL-LES) model and an augmented model that takes into account a wider range of nonlinearity. Applications to rough surfaces included drag-reducing microgrooves and non-homogenous roughness. In these settings the model provided insights into the underlying mechanisms. Mechanistic models to better understand how surface properties affected flow structures exploited the computational tractability of the simplified model.

Broader Impacts: The reduced order models developed in this project enabled exploration of the mechanisms underlying transitional and turbulent wall-bounded shear flows. A better understanding of the flow physics of wall-bounded turbulence has the potential to drive technological advances in a variety of applications such as aircraft, turbine design, pipe flow parasitic loss minimization, confinement of plasmas, and mixing strategies.  This work has also advanced the development of the knowledge required for building flow control strategies to, for example, reduce skin-friction drag; a major source of inefficiency that leads to greater fuel use and increases in both monetary and environmental costs.

The project partially supported a total of 5 graduate students, and 3 postdoctoral scholars.  The PI mentored one of these graduate students in teaching an undergraduate Hopkins Engineering Applications & Research Tutorials (HEART) course to help him gain teaching experience and expose undergraduates to concepts underlying reduced order models of turbulence. The project also supported a high school summer student, who helped develop new experiments for a fluid mechanics laboratory class.

Outreach activities through Johns Hopkins Open House programs, at local Baltimore elementary schools a JHU summer program for high school students and in the community emphasized the connections between fundamental fluid mechanics and sustainable energy in order to put the mathematics and science concepts in the context of pressing societal concerns, such as wind energy.  For example, the project supported wind energy activities at a local elementary school by the undergraduate Hopkins Student Wind Energy Team (HSWET) for whom the PI has served as faculty advisor since 2021.  The PI gave topical lectures at the Engineering Innovation (EI) pre-college program in each year of the project. In the final year of the project the students in the group provided lectures on wind energy in the newly created sustainable energy engineering (SEE) section of the EI program. Finally, PI Gayme's participation in the inaugural US version of Pint of Science at a local bar provided an interactive venue to explain wind energy and how wind farms can be controlled to provide power grid support to a broad local audience. The PI also participated and organized activities aimed at broadening participation at the annual American Physical Society Division of Fluid Dynamics meetings in each year of the project. For example, she co-organized the Faces of Fluid Dynamics lunch at the 2018 APS/DFD meeting aimed at sharing good strategies for increasing and supporting diversity at all levels of academia. She was a panelist at Faces of Fluid Dynamics lunch in 2019 and at the Minority Researcher event every year since its inception in 2019.

 


Last Modified: 05/03/2024
Modified by: Dennice F Gayme
